reviewText:
Played this from start to finish
Unbiased Review

After about more than a year since release, I decided to check this game out myself - to see whether the other reviewers might have been too harsh. Many of them played a few minutes and denounced it immediately. I have gone from start to finish. The game can safely be said to be 'complete', as in the developers won't add anything significant to better the experience. So why is this game so bad?

A few facts:
- 5 weapons available, where only 2 (wooden machete and M9 pistol) are actually used for most of the game
- Crafting boils down to merely creating bandages, you can complete the entire game without crafting anything else
- Crafting is limited to 7 items (8 in survival mode)
- There are a total of 4 kinds of enemies, that pose virtually no threat whatsoever, due to inferior AI coding
- The entire game can be completed in less than 4 hours
- Shooting inanimate objects causes them to bleed
- The single voice actor delivers his badly written lines in such way that you would quickly consider turning it off
- A great deal of the game takes place in a temple area (The Maze), this area is riddled with instant death traps that are springed upon you for the obvious reason to infuriate the player and slow progress further into the temple
- Level design makes frequent back-tracking unavoidable - in the maze it means constantly having to avoid the same traps over and over again
- All enemies respawn after loading a save
- Survival aspect in single player is negligable, due to readily available resources in all areas of the game
- Your biggest threat will be the rock throwing monkeys and instant death traps
- Animation quality is very low, this will be apparent from the very start of the game
- No quicksave, despite the fact that frequent saving is absolutely mandatory
- Most of the game mechanics rely on QTE's - bandaging takes about 20 seconds to complete

A note on the added survival mode:
A rather small section of the singleplayer map is isolated for you to 'survive as long as you can' - this entails running around in the day gathering food and crafting materials, then using a shelter to sleep at night. Due to the extremely barebones crafting system and the fact that everything is so easily obtainable, this experience does nothing to redeem the game whatsoever. If this kind of survival experience is desired, titles such as The Forest does this better in every aspect.

So tl;dr  - if you're looking for a survival game, there are plenty of other superior titles available. This game hasn't been too harshly judged by others, it fails in every aspect of gameplay from start to finish. For the morbidly curious, this game is an exercise in self-torture - it's not conducive towards any lulz whatsoever.

reviewText:
Oh dear, poor Garry has gotten himself into quite a sticky situation! First, Garry the humble bush pilot had a bit of a mishap during a not-so routine transport job due to Yellowstone’s Mount Saint Helena erupting right as he passed over it, resulting in a crash landing in the middle of...The Amazon jungle? If that wasn’t bad enough, Garry now needs to endure countless lethal cannibalistic natives chasing after him all over the place, puzzles that’ll test your patience and game-breaking bugs that are as hilarious as they are frustrating. Let’s take a look at Garry’s Incident.

So, here we have Day One: Garry’s Incident, Wild Games Studio’s brand new, first person, action-adventure survival game. You play as Garry, a pilot who just crashed into the jungle and soon realizes that, along with the aggressive and possibly very hungry natives, rock-flinging monkeys and badly animated panthers that will devour your heart without a second’s hesitation, there is also something else going on in this place. Something very strange. Something...alien.

That’s basically the whole story summed up. Now that we have that out of the way, let’s look at the gameplay, shall we? So, Day One is, if anything, ambitious. It combines a lot of different gameplay mechanics in an attempt to stand out from the crowd. Though the description of the game might have you believe that this is some sort of open-world, free-roaming survival simulator like Minecraft or Don’t Starve, Day One is much more linear than that. You still have some freedom to move about the lush jungle environments as you scavenge for supplies and resources to stay alive, but this is definitely no sandbox game.

Speaking of Minecraft, there are some comparisons to be made between it and Day One. In a somewhat similar fashion to Minecraft, you have a hunger meter that gradually depletes over time unless you find food via hunting, fishing or plucking fruit from bushes. Day One also has a similar crafting system, where you combine items you find and click a button to convert into new tools and other useful things. Though you can experiment with the system to craft items, you’ll also discover pieces of recipes as you explore the world. You’ll need to memorize these, because the game doesn’t log the recipe for you before you successfully craft an item on your own.

The crafting itself is simplistic and the inventory menu is sub-par, making the crafting more tedious than it has to be. Click the crafting tab, then click the items you wish to use in the crafting process, hit “craft” and you might make something. Every time you craft something you need to go through the exact same quicktime event, over and over again. In fact, QTEs are very commonplace throughout the game and you’ll get annoyed by them faster than you would watching Daniel Tosh do stand-up “comedy”.

Another issue with the crafting, that is also something that goes far deeper than that, is the fact that this and the hunger system are completely arbitrary. You will never really need to catch much food. In fact, you can stay alive on the random fruits you find around the world alone. This is in part due to the fact that the game only has a couple of hours’ worth of gameplay before you complete it. In other words, risking your life hunting panthers or combining dozens of random items in an attempt to make a fishing rod is absolutely pointless. You’ll never need to worry about finding water sources to drink from or refill your bottle for longer treks either. Just click C - the default “drink water at water source” button - and you can drink water directly. Anywhere. Yes, even if there is no water around.

Now, the aforementioned is obviously a bug and not intentional. Bugs are something Day One has a lot of. A LOT. I’ll give the developers some credit: they’ve released about five hundred million patches by now, improving upon the abysmal performance issues players had at launch and many of the worst game-breaking bugs. But even with most of the worst bugs now fixed - hell, BECAUSE many of the bugs are now fixed - it’s just so obvious that the game sorely lacks quality gameplay.

I mean, where do I even begin? Okay, let’s look past the bugs for a second. I’ve already mentioned how the crafting system is pointless. Beyond that, the game’s mandatory puzzles are incredibly tedious and often demand that you backtrack and search every single crevasse in the large environments to find that one thing that’ll let you continue.

At one point, you’ll find yourself trapped inside an enormous maze of underground tunnels, where you need to pull switches in order to align some statues that opens up a gate, allowing you to escape. This simple task is arbitrarily stretched out and made incredibly frustrating by the fact that the switches are scattered around the maze far from one another, and finding them all is a pain because you only have a crude map painted on the rock walls to guide you. There are plenty of dead ends too. Sure, the various traps you’ll encounter are cool and somewhat challenging to master, but walking around for hours looking for switches gets tedious fast. This is not engaging puzzle-solving, people! It’s clearly just a cheap attempt to artificially pad out the game. In fact, the entire game suffers from this problem; you can spend a dozen hours completing this game that only has about three hours of actual gameplay and believe me, that’s not meant as a compliment here.

The extensive list of mind-boggling design choices continues. The game employs a crude stealth system that allows you to sneak up on enemies and kill them in a single hit. However this system is also made pointless because you’ll find so much ammo for your two pistols that you can easily kill every enemy in the game without worrying about ever running out. What is the point of spending three minutes sneaking up on some native - or engaging in close combat with him that exposes the atrocious melee system with broken hit-registration and laughable animations - when you can just shoot him in the head and move on without risking your life? For a survival game, surviving isn’t all that hard. Well, for Garry, anyway. For you, as the player, it can be a tough test to endure the torment of this game.

At least the game looks kind of okay. The graphics aren’t high-end or anything, but the jungles have a lot of foliage, making them feel lush and alive. It’s quite ambitious for such a small game. Animations, however, are not good. The world design is confusing and repetitive. You’ll also get stuck on objects or invisible walls all the time and you can clip through objects and even the ground. The sound design wobbles between mediocre and horrendous. Aiming your weapon feels sluggish. The inventory menu feels like it’s a pre-alpha placeholder. The QTEs are never-ending and...the list just goes on and on. Let’s cut it off here, shall we?

I can sympathise with Garry Friedman. He’s in a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation. As was I, when I played this game. No matter how hard I tried to look for redeeming factors, I just couldn’t find any. When I finally reached the abrupt ending, I was disappointed that the game just wrapped up before it ever made use of any of its interesting mechanics and before it went anywhere with the story. But, at the same time, I was also happy that I was finally out of that hell. It’s obvious that the developers had a lot of ambitious ideas, but sadly the few mechanics that work are rendered pointless by the level design and the game-breaking bugs. Despite some glints of ambition here and there, even when ignoring the bugs, there isn’t anything here to warrant purchasing Day One: Garry’s Incident.

reviewText:
I don't think I have ever made a worse purchase. Keep in mind, I have bought Shaq Fu, Duke Nukem Forever, and even though I  don't like Call of Duty I still bought them to try them out. BUT THIS! This is by far the worst game I've played. I understand that it's being worked on, but more work should have been done before being put up for purchase. The combat is broken, I have no clue what I'm doing or where I'm going, the puzzles that I do find are too easy. You can take damage if you fall from a height slightly higher than your jump. Your gun...is not a gun. Guns kill people when you shoot them and the bullet hits the person. Here, it just mildly annoys them. But you! Oh you die really easily. You can take damage even if your hurting the enemy. You'll see them react to getting hit, they look like they can't attack you, but you still get hurt somehow!

The game is unplayable as it is. You get attack often giving you no time to heal and figure out what to do. Some could say this adds a chalenge, but I say if that is the case then it's an unfair one. I'm just glad that it has steam cards so I can get some of my money back.

Somewhere under all of the bugs, glitches and poor design choices, there is a good game. A game that can live up to the description the game gives you (the reason I bought this game thinking it might be good) but right now, unless the develepor can get some help, this game is not going to go anywhere.

reviewText:
Short version:

Prometheus, in eternal punishment, was chained to a rock where his liver was eaten daily by an eagle, only for it to be regenerated by night due to his immortality.
This game feels exactly like that.

Long version:

PROS:

-it ends, eventually, after having sucked the will to live out of you.

-they never made a second episode.


CONS:

-buggy, very buggy...cutscenes making you stuck, teleporting you to beginning or worse, you die for getting stuck to scenery ,you die while walking, your health meter bugs out, mobs can still hit you even if the animations don't play, unfinished game menu, alt tabbing makes the floor disappear, also CTDs

-graphics can look decent sometimes, but some parts have horrible models, also overall ugly textures

-background sounds and some music can be acceptable, but Garry's voice, enemy grunts and animal voices are subpar and get old fast

-story is almost non-existant, and what's there is either not explained or makes no sense whatsoever, also useless quest descriptions

-horrible AI, horrible enemy placement (easy to get swarmed by 6 monkeys)

-subpar controls, clunky, slow-ish, combat is basic and awfully animated, also I hope you enjoy having to go through a quicktime event every time you need to heal

-awful instadeath traps, so many of them, paired with the awful controls it gets frustrating fast

-bad level design, who knows where the levers you need are? also if you missed one, good luck going back to it passing the dozen or so instadeath traps

-the survival part is useless, I only crafted bandages, that's all, you get tons of food and water anyway...and the thirst/hunger bars deplete so slowly that they're not an issue anyway

-they never made a second episode, but they've managed to make another game, so yeah...there's that..

Overall, stay away from this....I've only played through it as a dare, and it was awful.

You deserve better than this, whoever you are.

reviewText:

1. Hit barrel with mangos in it.

2. Game black screens and freezes.

3. Game starts again with the barrel intact.

4. Hit barrel again.

5. Go through the floor and die.

6. Respawn and take mangos.

10/10 The uninstall button works

reviewText:
Short version:

Cons
1. Everything.

Pros
1. Protagonist has a beard. I like love beards.

Long version:

Alright, so as you've seen from the reviews, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. I honestly bought this game because I thought I could find genuine interest for it, but I was so wrong. Even for $0.99, this game isn't worth it. This game literally is competing for bottom place with Bad Rats- it's THAT bad. Allow me to go into further detail-

Music- There is little to none throughout this game. I started the game and noticed it from the get-go. There is a GIANT lack of music and it really ruins the mood for the game and ruins the playthrough for me because it's not nearly as dramatic as they wanted it to be. For instance, you'll start the game and soon after the temple you are in will start to collapse, but instead of crumbling noises from debris, it's just dead silence as you only hear you own footsteps. It's so lack luster and I think the game would be more enjoyable with more music in it.

Frame rates- This game is just horrible with it. Max settings on a GTX 950 doesn't even manage to get 60 FPS when I'm outside that temple....thing....whatever it is.... It's just so horrible. Low settings still struggles to keep a steady framerate, especially when outside and combat is involved. Combat is also clunky as hell, but so are the frame rates. Heh. This game is just so unoptimized, like, it's not even funny. There have been several updates claiming to have optimized" the game
date: but those patch notes are lies. These developers lied to my face by saying they optimized their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game for my sexy hardware. Bottom line
recommended: the framerates are bad/borderline unbearable even if you have a gaming computer.\n\nAnimations- Holy ♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
This game looks good in the store but once you actually install it and play it you realise why it has so many bad reviews.

For a start the graphics are awful. I mean you would think a game released in late 2013 would look good. Especially when games like Skyrim were out in 2011 for christ sake! But no! This piece of crap decided to use horrible graphics!

Then theres the story. It sucks! Basically you are a guy called Gary (No ♥♥♥♥!) and your plane crashes leaving you in a 'Mysterious' forest and you have to survive. And thats basically it as far as story goes, except for some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about a dead familiy.

Then of course theres the actual gameplay, you know seeing as this is supposed to be a game, basically its just your average survival game. Theres a crafting system (which sucks) , it lets you make stuff like medicine and bandages. You can find food to eat and drink water. You can interact wit locals by either killing them, trying to ignore them or do the occasional quest for them. Theres also weapons you can find. At the start you get a wooded stick, which for some strange reason is incredibly effective, later on you find an old timey double barreled pistol in a temple(WTF is it in a temple for?) and even later on you get a regular pistol, aside from that i dont know as i hated this game so much that i stopped playing it after that.  The ony other weapon i encountered was a magical one shot energy cannon that is permanently strapped to your wrist. Although its meant for destroying walls it can be used as a weapon. I personally loved the idea of this weapon but what i hated about it is that it only carries one shot and you practically never get to recharge it( which is done at altar thingies).The guns you get are ridicoulsly under-powered and pretty much useless, where as your stick is very effecttive. It can kill enemies pretty quickly and if you sneak up behind people you can do a pretty cool execution-style stealth attack which is one hit kill. What i hated were the enemies that i encountered. The most common enemies are natives and i kid you not, MONKIES!!!!! The navives are easy to kill as long as you use the afforementioned stealth attack but otherwise they are really hard to beat. The monkies are actually suprisingly difficult to kill considering what they are. They basically hide and throw rocks at you and if you don't find them they will kill you quite quickly, if you do find them they just run away and start throwing stones again. This brings me to another point, the natives will sometimes just ignore you but other times will completely randomly go ape-♥♥♥♥ and attack you. What i found most annoying about this is that if a monkey attacks you and you attack it it will sometimes run to a native who will then come and attack you, so you have to deal with two enemies at once!

Overall i personally really hated this game and would not recommend it to anyone. This game tried hard to be fun but in the end it failed and just ended up a bad far cry clone.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game and it was really fun too....
Are Wild Games Studios gone now?
Ok, this game was a pile of ♥♥♥♥. It was a pile of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ kebab forged from the very depths of the sewers. This game also stamps on those who try to talk ♥♥♥♥ about it hence my clever review disguise, you see?

I loaded up the game to be immediately greeted by a menu system that could only have been imagined by a man who'd have his testicles mounted on his wall, peering at them and polishing them at the weekends. I also noticed that this game also doesn't even have its own icon as it was still displaying the UDK icon for the game.
Ok, let's crank up the graphics. This game still uses the default variable names in menus - bAllowHighTextureMaterials...REALLY

I then started the game to find myself in a sacrificial chamber with the world's most oblivious temple priest of all time. I escaped from ropes that weren't even tied to anything to begin fighting him with a machete which I must of pulled out of my ♥♥♥♥. I killed him and there was no death animation, he just fell over dead and vanished into thin air.

I then started cutting down some lights and pushing buttons with my incredible arms that allow me to push buttons from a distance of 2 metres. Then for no explicable reason, the temple starts to crumble with broken rock meshes. I ran out of there and entered a cutscene which contained no sound at all.

I followed a girl to a village and had to do a stupid fetch quest for animal meat. I went down the dirt path and saw a panther which activated possibly one of the worst QTE's I have ever come across in my entire life. I killed it and stole his meat. I brought the meat back and then stopped giving two ♥♥♥♥♥ about the missions.

I continued the way I went before when I came across a pyramid. I climbed and there were many mirrors obviously placed for some kind of puzzle. I couldn't be asked and went back down the stairs again. Or atleast I would have if I hadn't died from fall damage by walking down the stairs. This showed me the death camera which would look like what I imagine a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fly's vision to be like. It was here I couldn't stand it any longer and quit.

Buy this game when it is super-cheap. I am 100% serious, you have to see this ♥♥♥♥! It's so apalling this game appeared to be more of a comedy!

reviewText:
EDIT: BY FAR THE WORST GAME IN HISTORY. The game is not only bad, but the Developers try to silence anyone who tries to warn others. I've submitted several discussions on the official page, only to find them removed withing seconds.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

What in essence is a brilliant idea, with some really great features like a crafting system (even if it is exremely limited), that enables you to make some neat tools and equipment such as: a shelter to sleep in, a fishing rod, and a water pouch for when you're feeling parched. I was very interested in trying out this game the concept is great; the final product, not so much.

Unfortunately it turned out to be one of the worst games I've ever played, the opening cutscene; the part that is meant to encapture the interest of the player is riddled with glitches. It begins with the protagonist blubbering like a baby to some guy who didn't know if he wanted to stand up or sit down, stand on the desk or stand IN the desk. I was willing to overlook the awful animation and unforgivable glithy-ness if the gameplay was at least half decent.

But unfortunatley the gameplay turned out to be so dull that it makes smashing your face into a wall seem like entertainment. Don't be fooled by the trailer, the combat is... how can I put this... glitchy, no that's not it... terrible? Nope, that's not it either. I suppose the only real way to describe it would be S**T!".  The game begins with the player being dragged off to some temple to be sacrificed by some locals who are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that your helicopter crash landed into their friends

reviewText: Rating this game a 2 out of 10 is being generous. Everything about it feels low effort, this is substandard for what a hobbyist UE3 modder might come up with. The game is tiny. You can run the entire circumference of the game world in about 3 minutes. It's populated by 4 NPC types. You have angry red diaper tribesman, angry brown bra tribeswoman, angry poo flinging monkey, and angry black cat. The bandages are bugged, if you cancel them before they finish you are healed full anyway and they are not consumed, so the survival aspect is out the window. Your supplies are virtually unlimited. The weapons make absolutely no sense. Your 9mm autoloader and your cap and ball pistol both reload by gently rubbing them. The game is plagued by technical flaws. Nothing feels right, nothing looks right. It's hard to explain, but everything is WONKY. That is the only word for the combat and movement in this game. Performance is inconsistent at best. The game doesn't even support my native resolution of 1360x768 so I played it in a window. But above all else, the sound design is horrific. I just played with the whole game client muted. The game is better muted than with sound on, trust me. You will never hear anything worse in your life as long as you live than the sound design of Garry's Incident.
voteText: 54 of 58 people (93%) found this review helpful 17 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The graphics resemble the first attempts of a 3D game on the PlayStation One system which allows the player to take an interesting journey back to when 3D games were challenging to see what things actually were.
I love the way the hit detection is made so that when you think you are hitting it, it doesn't actually hit them, it adds so much mystery to the game!
It's great the way that although it is a low resolution game, it lags like hell unless you are on a decent spec gaming computer! It prevents people that don't deserve this amazing game from playing it.
I especially like the way that the game developer gave this game to me for free and told me to give it a good review and tell my friends to buy it :) So that's what I'm doing!
If you are looking for a challenging game not for the actual challenge but the fact that the game handicaps the player, look no further! If you're looking for a game which is more dull than minesweeper, you've come to the right place!
It is great to force your friends to play! The storyline is really unrealistic too which adds a ton to the immersion.

Graphics - 10/10 (Very nostalgic of 3D games from 1998)
Gameplay - 10/10 (Brilliantly challenging, may be almost impossible to play!!)
Story - 10/10 (All the good parts of FarCry 3 removed to give you a nice nitty-gritty experience)
Music 4/10 (It sets the tone and style of the game and has a long and various soundtrack [Not for me!!] )

OVERALL A 10/10 WORST GAME EVER!

MUST BUY!

EDIT: So the game is now in the weeklong deals. That's fab, more people can experience the melted rainbow of a game that is Day One: Garry's Incidence. I am... happy... that Steam are behind this game and even went so far as to use it as a main game on their homepage. Steam would be making a mistake if they weren't endorsing this! Oh wait, no, the developer just bribed Steam to do it. Wow, that shows that the developer has the money and is therefore a great developer! I'm just going to go send him some money on PayPal.

Oh and some advice to the dev: If you made physical copies of the game, then the game would be worth almost 20 times as much by the value of plastic in the case and ink in the instruction manual. Maybe Gamestop will sell it? Just a thought.

reviewText:
Yay, I get to review this now!

Firstly, I am a huge indie games supporter, but check out http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QfgoDDh4kE0 as to why these devs deserve all the smacks on their collective wrists they can get. Then check out their metacritic page (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/day-one-garrys-incident) and laugh along at its awesomeness. 0.5/10 average user score after 1548 reviews.

Still, it came in the recent Bundle Stars indie game bundle, and surely can't be that bad right? Maybe just a victim of internet hate? And it has Steam trading cards, so it's pretty much me being paid to play it, right? Ha. Haha.

Let's see. The graphics are absolutely awful, simple, low-rez, stock graphics pasted together, primitive character models are pretty much just going through the motions with no facial expressions and really crude, robotic animations. Corpses despawn immediately upon death, though the background corpses that are there are violently graphic.

What little voice acting there is is dreadful, and really is just made up of short snippets (that often doesn't make total sense in the context - like Uh oh" when you fail a crafting combination
date: even though you don't lose anything for it) set to trigger when certain events happen. It takes several hits to bludgeon enemies to death and in the meantime they don't sound very perturbed by it.\n\nThe AI is deplorable
recommended: when you can shoot npcs from range and they often won't come for you as they slowly die
hoursPlayed: nor do any of their friends around them. You can even sneak right up behind an npc

column17: that shows off exactly how poor and juvenile their animations are.\n\nThe plot makes no sense

column19: and there is no plausible explanation why things happen the way they do
column20: like why that plasma weapon was sitting where it was or how the guy knows it's going to float up to attach to his arm or why/how he can still change weapons after that. NPCs will appear out of and walk through solid objects at will

column22: and you will find dumb bugs like how boxes during that escape portion can fall on your head and trap you inside their model without the game registering a death and forcing you to load or anything.\n\nAnyway I'm out of negative adjectives

reviewText:
To readers: Due to steam can't accept more than one review per game, I'll write any review with: English - most Steam users' main language and Chinese - my native language, language will be set to English. Hope you understand, and thank you.

In a word: Good for the idea, bad for a game.一句话：创意不错，游戏太渣。
I buy this game for it's concept, the weird story, the nice crafting system I think, and open world. But after my installation, I found the game totally bad optmization, and... WHAT THE [Beep]ING MARLETT FONT ON THE WALL?? I can't enter scene 2 just bacause my laptop is not so good? So, I feel sad for this game, and the developer, very sad.
之前购买这个游戏是看中了其创意和特别的故事，还有开放世界和我认为极好的加工系统。但装完了才发现，这游戏实在是优化太差，然后……墙上的Marlett字体的文字是怎么回事儿？然后……我竟然因为我本子太差进不了第二个场景！？这游戏和其开发者真的太令我伤心了。

Pros / 优点Weird story, maybe interesting;  /  诡异到可能很有趣的故事；
Nice crafting and item using.  /  不错的加工和物品使用方式。
Cons / 缺点Bad optmization;  /  优化差；
Weird bugs;  /  怪异的BUG；
Perfunctory Marlett font on the wall(Sorry, I just can't appect it);  / 墙上那敷衍的Marlett字体……抱歉，我受不了；
No more, sorry. Because I have't play too deep, this game just prevent me for this. :(  /  抱歉没有更多了，我玩的不多，因为这游戏根本没法让我继续下去。 :(

reviewText: This game is the jurassic park trespasser of modern gaming, It tries to bring something which hasn't been done very often and has some ambitious ideas which is why I wanted so hard to enjoy the game but it's just not fun. The crafting and survival system is about as in depth as farcry 3. The combat is terrible, guns don't sound anything like they should and melee is clumsy. Day one looks and plays like a game released 7 or 8 years ago. The story from the beginning cutscene is almost non existant, read the plot on the product page to have any idea what is going on. As for variety of enemies we have panthers, evil tribals and monkeys throwing rocks, avoiding spoilers there is on more type but nothing exciting. One problem that really needs to be adressed is tabbing back to steam and back in screws up the video in game had to restart every time. Really couldn't recommend getting this game no matter how hard i try to like it.

reviewText:
My thoughts go out to anyone who, for whatever reason, bought this thing at full price. After 1 hour playing Day One: Garry's Incident, I was overcome with a feeling of shame for ever giving any other game a bad review, because the reason for those just seem petty now in comparison.

The game starts with a cutscene drenched in screen tearing even though vsync was enabled. I then find myself (as Garry) strapped to a stone altar of sorts in the second cutscene after which I must perform an action (mashing a button) to free myself before an awfully animated shaman ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sacrificially stabs me. During this whole scene there is absolutely no ingame sound, not even crickets. It's like they forgot to include the sound files related to that event in the game.

After freeing myself and making that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ animation meet its demise, I find this scantily clad indigenous babe chained next to the altar and I'm faced with the choice of either freeing or killing her. Being a gentleman (one who sports a blade in case things go sour anyways) I decide to let her go, but I'm using a gamepad and the controls I'm being shown onscreen keep switching randomly between keyboard and gamepad directions, so I end up having to guess what to press only to hear her whimper as I kill her accidentally. Now she's dead, oh welp. I hit her again because... because yes, and she blurts out the same cry. And again, and again, and again. Outstanding. From now on it can only get better.

Now I'm wandering around the temple until I find a piece of cloth and get instructions to craft it into bandages. I do that, and then I place two bandages in the crafting window to see if I could further combine them, and that's when our Garry says it out loud: UH-OH!" and the game just crashes
date: with an UDK failure pop-up on Windows and all. That was actually funny because it seemed like he had suddenly become sentient (with a touch of clairvoyance) to our out-of-game reality
recommended: and I would naturally have considered a feature like that a pro
hoursPlayed: had I not found after relaunching the game that Garry says that every time you try to combine un-craftable things. Disappointment.\n\nVoice acting is not something I'm picky about
voteText: but here it is a thing to behold. I feel however I lack the vocabulary to describe something like that
helpfulPercent: and that it would be like trying to transcribe the humour in someone else's stand-up comedy act through written word. YouTube is just around the corner if you're curious.\n\nGiven the red wall of top rated negative reviews glaring at you from the front page of the game's store

commentsCount: masochistic or possess some real next-level avant-garde sense of irony to buy this game.\n\nBut if like me you got this in a bundle (with other games that you wanted) for nearly nothing

reviewText:
I don't know how I wound up with Gary's Incident in my account, but it was there when browsing through my Steam library. I fired it up, interested in seeing if it was really as bad as . . . everyone -- literally every one . . . has ever said. After all, I tend to be a contrarian. Maybe it has some redeeming qualities.

After playing for a bit, I can confirm that it does not. Everything about Gary's Incident feels like a very early iteration of a high school first time 3D UDK development project. If a young person came up to me and presented this to me as their creation, I would be highly impressed. Unfortunately, when I come to Steam, I expect professional-quality projects created by actual game developers -- even if independent. What I don't expect is someone's janky first-time project.

Don't pay for this. If you get it for free, don't waste the bandwidth downloading it. Don't waste your time playing it. I am worse for having wasted precious moments of my life on this thing.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game. I repeat, DO NOT buy this game! It will keep you captivated for hours on end and nothing else will be important to you any more - not your friends, not your family, not work, hell, not even eating or sleeping! The story line is thrilling - I mean, an alcoholic pilot transporting magical artifacts over the Yellowstone Caldera which happens to erupt with no warning and then being teleported to an Amazonian temple? GENIUS! Give the storywriter a medal! Oh, and the bugs are just to die for! Both of my saves are bugged so badly that they are unplayable, one where I am stuck underground and the other where I fall repeatedly through the world and die on spawn - and I'm only 5 minutes in! The bugs add an additional challenge that will entertain and excite all gamers, casual and hardcore alike! Oh, and the nostalgic graphics that take you back to the early 90's? Absolutely wonderful, it's almost as if the developers knew what we were craving for!! Meanwhile, the death animations are faultless - dropping with no elegance and disappearing almost immediately off the face of the Earth. Let's be honest, nobody wants to see a corpse lying around and nor do they need an over the top, dramatic ragdoll effect when you end a poor fools miserable life. You must be thinking 'I must buy this, what more could these Gods amongst men possibly provide us?'. Well, Don't get me started on the acting! Seriously, how these guys haven't cracked Hollywood is beyond me! The same monotonous tone is used throughout, whether it is making a comment whilst slaughtering a poor, innocent captive or stubbing your toe on the floor as you pass through it to an untimely, buggy doom. This familiarity is a necessity in the gaming world, allowing you to know exactly who you are still without breaking out of the captivating immersion!

Oh, and did I mention that the game also allows you time to reflect on it's own brilliance in the form of lag and over the top loading times, even with a £1000 well specced PC? Just a little extra given to us by the amazing Wild Games Studio!


0/10 Would buy!

reviewText: The exploding volcano and teleporting plane raised my initial interest, but it only lasted 20 minutes. I stopped playing after coming down from the 'pyramid' and getting oneshotted by one of the natives. The game definitely needs more polish.\nThe jungle area seemed very confined, with lots of narrow paths surrounded by unpasable walls. I had flashbacks to the forest areas of Zeno Clash and the jungle area of Lands of Lore 2.\nThe saving system is problematic - it doesn't fully record the state of the world. On game load, enemies seem to respawn (even set pieces), destructible obstacles are back, and the action sequence screen shake isn't there anymore. The loading times drained my patience since I was getting killed every minute.

reviewText:
I'd heard about this game through TV Tropes and TotalBiscuit, so when I happened to get it as part of a bundle I decided to try it out.

It certainly lives up to its reputation.

See, this game uses a titanic amount of memory, which... limits its framerate somewhat.  Forget advancing through the story.  Forget survival challenges.  Hell, forget looking for amusing glitches.  Simply moving from point A to point B is an aggravating ordeal.

I can deal with the abrupt instant kills, the gratuitous invisible walls, the overly simplistic stealth mechanics, and even those damned monkeys, but not when the framerate feels like my screen is grinding against my eyes.

The worst part is that this could have been bad in a funny way.  Like, for example, one time I tried to shoot an enemy from atop a pyramid, but not only did an invisible wall block my shot, the ricochet killed me!  I still didn't have my last trading card, so I spent the next few minutes killing myself against that invisible wall, just to pass the time.  Unfortunately, if this game is ever brought a playable state, most of the more entertaining problems will probably be fixed as well.  Too bad.

Anyway, don't buy this.  If you get it in a bundle, don't install it.  This game is painful to play.  Leave it be.

reviewText:
Do you like games that spawn you under the map and kill you over and over? Do you like horrible guns that miss at point blank range? Do you like very stupid monkeys throwing rocks at you while they face the other way, and still hit you? Do you like crappy voice acting and crappy AI? If yes,  DONT BUY THIS TRASH ANYWAYS. Im embaressed to even have played this game. What did my computer do to deserve to have to run this garbage? This game is so broken that, you could clone Bob the builder 100 times and still no be able to fix it. Its called Day One because Garry could only take on day of this crap. I had to kill a bunch of monkeys, is that what games have come to? Killing little moneys? How can i call myself a man knowing i had to do that crap? The temple with all the traps took me three diffrent playing sessions, because i could not take the awful layout and setup. When you try to craft somthing and learn you can't, big bad Garry simply says 'UH OH'. I mean really, you dont say? The panther was stolen from a ps 1 game from the looks. When you stealth kill people they freeze up and fall over, and the women have the same sounds as the men when they die. The health bar is a joke because sometimes i die in one hit with full health, other times i get hit 5 or 6 times and some how poor Garrys still kicking. This game is like torture to play. I bought it because i knew it would be bad, but never could i have imagined this bad. The amount of time I die from a glitch, or even for no reason what so ever, is outrageous.

1/10 One point for making me rethink my life, trying to figure out what lead to me buying this.

P.S. This game made my guinea pig cry, I hope you're proud devs.

reviewText:
I played this game for a little over an hour and a half and I really wanted to like it.  I kept making excuses for the stupid mechanics and having no idea why I was taking damage or why I could bump into a guard while sneaking up on them and they had no idea I had ran into them.  After all the frustration, I decided to come back to the store page to see if there were any updates listed or any dates on when it would come out of Early Access" alpha or beta stage it was in.  Then I realized... this wasn't an early access game.  The developers actually think this is a finished production quality piece of work.  Wow.  That is sad.

Collision detection doesn't work.  Damage seems to be broken.  Weapons are unbalanced.  The special weapons you see in the movie are basically one shot items for the most part because they have to be recharged and there is no recharger point.  The blue glowing magic rocks embedded in your arm weapon?  I got it... but I have no idea how to use it and it is not in the weapons list when I scroll through.  I saved the amazon queen only to have her stand up and immediately disappear which froze my screen.  I waited about 15 seconds and then I got control back and it told me that I had cooked some meat.  Uh... I was no where near a fire.

This game has flaws and its flaws seem to have flaws.  There is potential here but even if all the mechanics were fixed
date: I still wouldn't want to play it for the inane voice overs that this guy spews.  Its like they wanted to be funny like the original Duke Nukem games but have no idea what funny is.\n\nDo not buy this game."

reviewText: I wish I could find something redeemable to say about this game, and believe me I'm still searching for something...  The reality being this is a very buggy, very boring and ugly game, and charing $20 for it blows my mind.  I was mildly amped at first to try a FPS survival game, but it falls short in every way possible.\n\nI can overlook the clunky graphics.  I cannot however overlook the numerous invisible walls, the horrid and boring combat and at times frequent see-through-walls syndrome.  I also want to smash my keyboard every time some mundane action or task comes up and you are forced to do mind-numbing quick-key actions.  This game feels like it'd be at home on the Wii to purchase in the online store for $2.99, but do yourself a favor and definitely do not pick this up for $19.99.  Maybe wait until a massive sale and pick it up as a gag gift for someone you don't like that much on your friends list.

reviewText:
This game is unfinished, unpolished and though it has nice ideas it isn't worth the money in its current state!

The Reviews on the Steam page were promising and it was on discount so I bought this game. It didn't say Early-Acces, it was sold as finished work. What I got is a game that feels tremendously UNFINISHED! The animations are artificial, I have seen better graphics in Far Cry(2004!). The sound is cheap and so is the voice acting. The graphics use a lot of performance and heat up the system. The menu overlay is quirky, slow and unresponsive. The combat system is dull. You can kill one of the friendly NPCs and noone notices or get hostile. Everything looks like they stopped developing half way.
I'm willing to accept minor quirks when the concept is good and when it was developed thoroughly. But for the price of around 20€ the quality has to be a lot higher. And sadly they failed with this game and I feel like I wasted my money on this.
voteText: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
THis game isn't good. At all. It tries to have a crafting system, but then the crafting system doesn't really even do much at all. And the things it does do, there's no way to find out how to craft them unless you just pure trail and error it. The story is god awful (at the start of the game, you have to untie yourself after being captured by tribals, AND THE GUY JUST STANDS THERE AND WATCHES YOU GET OUT), the animations are even worse than the story.

The game also falls under the whole 'every game needs a gun' rule, apparently. Without even explaining it, you find an old flintlock pistol thing, and literally 2 minutes or less later you find a modern glock. I mean, what the hell is exactly happening in this game? And I just stopped playing after they make MONKEYS in the game the most dangerous thing. Don't buy, don't try.

Also, there's a reason why the game dropped from 20 bucks to 5. Cash grab. Only reason I have is becasue they tricked my friend into thinking it was good and they bought it for me as a suprise... made me feel bad when I said that it was the worst game ever.

reviewText:
Nosebleeds
To many bugs in startup. To many workarounds to get the game running, not even a decent pre-setup to do some finetuning on the game. All this reminds me of games made in the 90s when most setups weren't required since everybody either owned a CGA, EGA, VGA or SVGA card. And there were only Adlib and Soundblaster cards for sound.

Well, at those times you got at least a game running even IF your Ram wasn't high enough, you could do finetuning with some kind of memory manager. In this game you are first greeted by... Locked Display error, after you solved this little trouble you get to know the slow flash mode of the game, alternating between black screen and desktop - with no normal way to interrupt the game but to restart the computer. After you have solved this problem, you see a screen and video with some glitches (No, I have two computers one with integrated graphics and the other with a high end graphics adapter - it's the same with both).

So recomendations? What for? For a game which might have been a good game if the programmer worked on a broader basis and didn't try to enforce their own narrow side of game design? For a game full of bugs, glitches and frustrating workarounds? Steam would do a good thing to remove their approval and remove the trading cards on this game. Supporting a narrow set of boards and configurations is always a bad thing.

This game would get zero points out of ten for bad conduct. Prospects and after release debugging aren't a good way to start, especially when the prospects don't come even close to the expectations one held for a game.

reviewText:
This truly is 'The Room' of videogames.

Story Mode is filled with bugs and glitches, a very vague plot that you can't quite make out but with impeccable dialogue from the enthusiastic VA for Garry. Sometimes models will disappear from your hands, the crafting is all quick time events, for some odd reason the foliage sometimes grows in size and shrinks as you move closer.
UDK showcases it's true beauty when you ALT+TAB and all the textures stretch to the moon and back, improving the gameplay quality ten-fold. The monkeys are all OP, the humanoid enemies deal a lot of damage but can just be easily outsmarted by moving slightly to the left or right and the panthers are quick time events with Garry yelling IS THAT ALL YOU GOT?!"

God forbid you try out the wonderful Survival Mode which consists of one loading screen
date: a lovely 5 second shot of Garry plunging into some beige looking void along with a very manly scream which then results in death and being sent back to whatever last save you had over in the Story Mode.\n\nThere's no actual graphics options
recommended: just extras like V-Sync and Dynamic Shadows except for one box you can tick called Detail Mode which I suspect means "Do you want graphics?".\n\nI can't say I would or wouldn't recommend this game...it's an experience though I can tell you that."

reviewText:
I went into this game having forgotten everything about it when it was launched. It started off promising with no sound effects until the first guy was dead. After which, he vanished. I then found a captive lady who I promptly killed, and continued to make the same horrific death sound about 10 minutes afterwards. The instructions on the walls were very subtle, so much so I spent a long time in the first area because I was captivated, I mean lost.

After I had managed to get out of the first room after the huge stone structure slid across the room like it was on ice, I managed to escape the temple. I then had my flask stolen, and was promptly instructed to follow the glittery path the thief left. When they stopped, I shot her. To which I was prompted with a static version of the model...and my flask back. Kill the entire village (all of which made feral sounds when they died). One shot a panther....to die from a monkey because it was funny as running around flinging what I can only assume was poo at me. Death by poo is not fun by the way.

When trying to remember what about  this game seemed so familiar, I remembered that a few youtube commentors had reviewed it and got the book thrown at them because of it. I can't understand why, because they were telling the cold hard truth. This game feels and looks like it was built by a single todler. Half the menus get this weird yellow box around it which stops the rest of it from working, the controls feel like I have my hand up Garry's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and controlling him through his rectom. The combat is poor, the special effects" look like they came from 2001...and this was built on the Unreal 3 engine. An engine which has been used many times to produce beautiful games. I didn't even think it was possible to ♥♥♥♥ up a game this badly since that DayZ rip off.....wait a minute.

In closing
date: this review is something you should read before buying
recommended: or playing this horrendous game. I bought this in a bundle of 6 or so other games for about $4AUD
hoursPlayed: and even then I feel ripped off. After writing this
voteText: I'm going to promptly take the hard-drive it is installed on and burn it
helpfulPercent: as there is no other way to remove that vast amount of ♥♥♥♥ off an electronic device.\n\nP.S. If the developer is reading this

reviewText: Game feels unfinished. Not even like a beta but an alpha. No sound effects, very buggy, invisible walls, no objects climbable, not even the stair-like platforms on village huts, main menu would sometimes superimpose itself on top of a ghost image of a menu you tried closing, combat is very clumsy, opening cinematics render with video defects.\n\nIf this game was still under development I would recommend it as promising. But as it stands as a finished product, it's terrible and almost unplayable. If you finish this game, you likely have the patience of a saint.

reviewText: I'm getting dizzy just by looking at the title of the game in my library. I'm literally in a near-puke state, at any time i can puke all over my PC, and I'm not even joking. The graphics are HORRIBLE, it caused me eye cancer several times while playing. There are lag issues. The textures are buggy as hell. What more can I say? OHHH. QTEs. The worst kind of. There are so many quick time events, that it's just irritating. For example, when healing, drinking, when getting attacked by a ♥♥♥♥ing panther every single time and so on. The crafting is okay, not too bad, not too good. The AI is messed up. Sometimes enemies charge at you from 3000 miles away, and sometimes they are just standing there, with their beautiful glowing blue eyes. Oh, not forget to mention, the sneak-system is not working, they will always find and attack you. There are 3 types of enemies if i'm correct: the natives, the ♥♥♥♥ing monkeys, the humoncoulous' (they appear on trading cards), and waaaay too many traps, which are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to avoid(especially the axe). It isn't survival-horror. It's only survival-horror for you, because this game is so damn broken on many-many levels. It's like the movie Ring, but in this case, playing the game will surely cause you cancer, leukemia, AIDS, and death, all at once. The story is dumb, maybe i'm stupid or something, but I just can't understand the plot. You are flying all over the place, when suddenly a big BANG, a volcano erupts, and your plane is going down becasue of a plasma hellgate, or i don't what is it. And you have that blue stuff on your plane. I don't know what it is, it's just confusing. Alright, so you landed, and you wake up in a temple with a bone sword or something like that, it's just useless. The enemies will kill you faster, and oh, the blocking is broken too. Sometimes it's effective, sometimes not. There are 3 levels if I remember correctly, and the ♥♥♥♥ing maze is the most frustrating part, when you have to move head statues. That map is filled with traps, like swinging axes, which are the hardest part to avoid, because the hitbox of the axe is too big, there are falling floors,  spears coming out of walls, and wall spike thingies. I've played this game for 3 frustraing hours, because i wanted to see the poor ending. And well, well, I was right. There was no ending at all, some alien ships came by, and just a to be countined" screen. PLEASE DON'T MAKE THE SEQUEL. God knows how many poor souls have been devoured by this miserable game. And finally
recommended: HURRAY! FREE! It's strange that the DLC isn't at least 10-20 euros. At least they were aware of their capabilities. Alright

reviewText:
I saw the reviews and thought to myself that this game can't be as bad as people say. The game starts off with a nice intro sequence making you think that it was worth the money you spent on this, but when you get in game, the lack of effort put into this is phenomenal.

Pros:
- Okay graphics, I'm being modest. It kinda looks pretty.
- Crafting, the crafting minigame is 10x better than the game itself. (it gets annoying after the first time though)
- There's food. If that makes a change. I guess it's a nice feature.

Cons:
-Missing sounds, lots of audio bugs.
-Missing textures, lots of graphical bugs.
-The most threatening enemy are monkies.
-AI for the human enemies are not intellegent at all. No pathfinding skills and has an area of awareness around them, making stealth impossible.
-The weapons are the following: Bone Machete, Old Pistol (Flintlock pistol), Modern Pistol and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Alien Wristrocket. The bone machete doesn't do crap, the old pistol is a two hit kill and the modern pistol and wristrocket are 1 shot kills. You are way too OP in this game against the tribe people.
-Lack of Explanation. Why did your plane crash and why the hell are the monkies OP and kill you slowly and silently? ( This would probably be explained if I finished the game, I just couldn't bring myself to do it)
-Saving is trash. If you're saving to quit and play again another day, you'll be lucky to not find your save file corrupt. You have to play through Garry's Accident in one sitting.
-The puzzles are annoying, extremley simple yet take forever to solve.
- You have a hunger and Thirst bar but don't worry about getting food and water, they don't decrease because it's broken like this game overall.

Don't buy this. I wanted to laugh at how bad this is but I can never get my money back, sadly. I even bought it on sale for $1 and it still wasn't even worth it. Seems like they spent a lot of their budget in the intro sequence because it's just a downward spiral from there.

reviewText:
This is Temple Run out of the map in first-person.

Your first mission is to get out of a temple after you've killed some indian-egypt-african-aztec-dude, who for some reason doesn't know how to tie a rope probably so you can't escape. Why the f* can't he do that, when he has lived in the jungle since he was brought into that weird world by his mother when she died. --- And i say when she died, because everytime you kill a chick it sounds like she gives birth to an idiotic child with rabies.

You only know what to do in the start and the rest of the game you run around and a pretend you're Bear Grylls lost on Madagascar. There's seriously monkeys running around throwing mangos at you, because they don't feel like eating that god damn mango. If i had a mango right now i would eat it. Those monkeys are some little unthankful c*nts and i hope they get stuck in some top secret mayan stone-trap and get crushed by a giant rock until their eyes pop out.

But this thing actually is has a positive side too! You wouldn't believe it would you? Well.. If you don't have money for a Far Cry-game and just want cut animals open, you can do that! There's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pumas running around the jungle, which you can skin with the exact same animation they use in Far Cry! Though it's really bad because it's Day One: Garry's Incident". They should call it "10 minutes: That's the game".

Anyways.. This is great game! ... *cough* if you got dropped as a child on the floor *cough*.

By the way. Why does the main character have so huge hands? Like really. It's like he's Bigfoots cousin."

reviewText:
I wish steam reviews would offer a sideways thumb option rather than a straight up/down thumb option, as I don't want to be forced to praise or condemn Day One: Garry's Incident. The deluge of derision this game has received is legendary and I don't want to be party to those kinds of criticisms.

Does that mean Day One: Garry's Incident is a great game? Absolutely not. It's a severely mediocre game but certainly not as bad as other tried-and-true bad games.

It feels more like a demo for something bigger but cut short by lack of funds or time (or both).

Moreover, Day One feels like the developers couldn't settle on what kind of game they wanted to make.

Is it a survival sim? No. It has a loose bit of survival-lite" mechanics but that's about it. The survival aspect feels completely tacked on and has very little to do with the overall game or story. The survival mechanics are just a surrogate for more traditional ways of healing in other first-person adventures.

Is it an FPS? Barely. As FPS goes Day One is clunky
date: slow and awkward. The weapons are uninspired and only the pistol and the alien blaster-thingy are any good. The other weapons are pretty useless. The enemies are\n\nIt is a rip-roaring Indiana Jones-esque adventure? Maybe but the puzzles and traps are poorly designed as to suck any fun the game might have. The traps throughout are tedious trial-and-error speed bumps that force you to save often. The puzzles are dull and equally tedious; the temple complex in the second act
hoursPlayed: forces the player to hunt down a half-dozen switches to open up the way to the next level
voteText: spread out over a ginormous Mayan temple that dwarfs the player that even running non-stop feels slow.\n\nGarry's Incident should be a lesson to its developers: develop a focus; fine tune your gameplay; make sure it's fun. This is where Garry's Mod fails. I can't help think if the developers had just made the effort they could have had a decent game on their hands but instead opted to make a quick buck and release it in a shoddy state."

reviewText:
The game is still dropping the keybindings for controls, making it unplayable STILL!

I have to reinstall the config files from the original download, redo ALL the setup, and can play for less then 5 minutes before it drops the keybindings again - rinse & repeat.

Forget about any incentives to buy like the $100+ dollars in steam games contests.

If you can't play the game you can't win the contest.

The forums have people talking about completing the game (Usually in under 6 hours) and I'd like to know how they kept it from crashing for 6 hours.

Don't waste your money on this tragedy.

If your really interested in this game, wait a year then check the games forums.

If you find more how do I complete this mission/objective" then "how do I run this game"
recommended: I want my money back then it MIGHT be stable enough to try."

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ing A this game is awful. From naming the game to sound like an amalgamation of DayZ and Garry's mod, to censoring youtube videos critical of this game, the developers are shady as hell and some of the worst I've ever seen.

The first minutes of gameplay had no sound, mysteriously enough, and when I died from an unknown reason I respawned into a big hazy empty space from which I fell endlessly, dying again. Every subsequent respawn had me floating in the same place, even when I quit the game and started the survival mode, a mode COMPLETELY separate from the main game.

Nope, spawned way in the sky, and died over and over again. Only when I completely exited out of the program did I manage to play.

And what did I do? Chase monkeys around and beat them to death with what looked like a wooden machete which isn't as  nearly as amusing as it sounds.

It's like somebody giving me a bag of ♥♥♥♥. I couldn't resist taking a look because there were so many others talking about this bag of ♥♥♥♥. But yep, it's ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: I'm looking at you, people who pick up games because they're on sale. I don't care if this game is cheap right now. DO NOT BUY IT.\n\nI really wanted this game to be good. I mean really. You have the ceilling falling and it makes no sound? Come on guys. I had no idea what to do in most of the game. I was stuck in the first room for the majority of my play time because there was to indication of what to do. And the things you were supposed to find where practically hidden in shadows. Come on game, it's the first room. It's not supposed to be a scavenger hunt.

reviewText:
Day One: Garry's Incident does not fail because it's a bad game. It fails because it is an incomplete game. Parts of the game work well, and parts of it don't.

Graphics: 6/10
In-game: 8\10
Cutscenes: 4\10

The graphics in-game are genuinely beautiful, and I'm honestly surprised I got it to work this well on my computer, the cutscenes are a different story though... In the opening cutscene, Garry clearly dumps his liquor onto his crotch before drinking from it, and his other movements simply look unnatural.

Sound Design: 4\10
Voice Acting: 6\10
Sound Effects: 2\10

The voice acting, while not AAA, professional quality, is adequate. The sounds are adequate as well, when they work. Half the time, it seems that the sound effects simply cut out.

Gameplay: 6\10
Combat: 3\10
Controls: 9\10

I had absolutely no problems controlling the game, except for the overuse of quick-time events, but I had actually never experienced them before, so I'm not sick of them yet. The combat is set up so that you have two kinds of attacks and one way to block, but you can take out most enemies with the first attack alone, since it stuns them long enough for you to hit them again.

MINOR SPOILER ALERT: The scene where the temple is collapsing around you at the beginning is genuinely awesome.

Stability: 1\10

Here's where the game really has its problems. Bugs are everywhere. Rather than an in depth analysis of them, I'll just tell you my experiences with them.

Dies, loads autosave, falls out of the world, repeat about five times before I manage to shut down the game.

Loads save file, encounters frozen tribe leader, opens inventory, game freezes, weeps silently.

Low on health, uses bandages, ceiling caves in while I'm using them, finishes bandaging myself up, teleports to the sacraficial table without my pistol and magic gauntlet, weeps openly

Enjoyability: 7\10

If you like bad games, or are looking for a joke gift for a friend, this game is perfect. Or if you like survival games and are willing to look beyond what are admittedly huge flaws then you could get some enjoyment out of it.

Overall: 4.8\10

Overall, if you're looking for the next great survival game, you will be disappointed. But if you've heard how infamous this game is and still want to try it, you will get what you're looking for.

reviewText:
Well I have very little to say about this game that is positive.  The game has the potential to be a fantastic game, but that's where to upside ends.

The game is buggy beyond all means.  I first started noticing bugs on the title screen,  I mean if you can't even get the title screen correct, what's the point in trying to complete the game.

Then there's the issue of their scripts pretty well kill you even when you have won the button mashing tasks they give you.  I got into a struggle with a panther & even though I won the struggle, the outcome was that both the panther & myself ended up dead requiring me to reload the game.  I decided to shut it off rather than reloading.

The worst part of the game is not the game itself, but the developers.  There has been a lot of controversy surrounding this game since it was released & most of it has to do with abuse of the legal system to censor legitimate bad reviews.  There are a number of allegations that Wild Games Studio has also made false metacritic & other positive reviews to boost their game (I don't know if there are any actual facts in this, but there's a TON of information on Wikipedia[en.wikipedia.org] about it.

I would probably recommend this game in the future if the developers could fix the majority of the bugs, but at this time I would have to say that somebody would have to have some extremely bad luck to even have this game gifted to them.  This game still doesn't top the situation with WarZ/Infestation: Survivor Stories by Hammerpoint Interactive, but it isn't far off...

Games like this & WarZ/Infestation: Survivor Stories are the reasons why allowing indie games to get on Steam was probably a bad idea, it only tarnishes Steam's rep.  I would have to say that this game should probably be removed from Steam, but first off we know the developers are going to put up a fight over it & secondly, we may never see any fixes to the numerous bugs currently in the game.  I have no idea why WarZ/Infestation: Survivor Stories was even re-added to Steam, that game is an obvious scam if I ever saw one & a blatant ripoff of other games, movies, etc.; the lawsuit against them from Warner Bros. was proof enough of that.

reviewText: I give it a 2/10, 3/10 if I want to be optimistic. Gameplay tends to be laggy and uninspiring, and what little plot there is seems woefully lacking in terms of storytelling elements.  An information that *might* be useful in learning how to play via pop ups, which tend to trigger about half a minute after they would've been of use.  Combat elements are simple enough, but the lack of telegraphing tends to make melee fights a matter of luck more than skill...  And the game in general seems prone to various bugs.\n\nI bought this for roughly $1 USD while it was for 90% off... and I'm not sure I got my money's worth. :/
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, it looked like it had a good deal of promise. I thought $4 was a good price to pay for it, that it was worth a shot at that price. I was wrong.

I should have listened to the overwhelming array of negative reviews. It seems to be using an old Unreal engine, like maybe the Unreal 2 engine or something, and the controls are just awkward. There are slowdowns (for seemingly no reason), long loading times, and this all spells a bad experience without even getting into the poor graphic quality and poor audio quality (yes, I know it's indie, I took that into account).

Trying to exit the game after my 47 minutes of buggy playtime was an experience in itself. My system hung on a black screen for around 10 minutes (couldn't even CTRL+ALT+DEL), and my computer was slow for another 10 or so minutes after that with the harddrive being hammered the whole time. It even managed to crash the audio driver in Ventrillo (which I was logged into in the background). The error message said something about too much data being forced through the sound driver.

Overall, my experiences with Day One were not unique, and I just cannot recommend this game to anyone.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
game is extremely awkward to play (controls and playstyle)

the crafting system is a horrible and isn't as good as it is advertised and proves to be next to useless

the game's physics are so overdone that it made my computer lag (one that can run skyrim with a ton of texture and physics booster mods including more and better foliage, realistic water particles, hi-res textures, light bloom and the like with no visible lag) as well as one that can support BF4

the game could have been a wonderful survival adventure game, hower the sci-fi aspect was pushed way too far and the interaction system is horrible (need to focus on a single point on an object in order to interact with it)

the mouse and keyboard controls are clunky and awkward to use, the mouse isn't as responsive and smooth as it should be, and the gamepad controls aren't any better

The graphics are decent but as stated before they implemented an extremely high amount of physics into this where there didn't need to be any, I wish they had put as much time that they had into the environment, into the engine and gameplay

I say 1/10 at least the thing ran (barely) Definitely not worth the money and I wish I hadn't bought it

reviewText:
This game has had so many chances to be updated to a better game, scene as though it was made in september last year, but it's possibly the worst game I have played in a while, and that includes Ride to Hell...

Please note that I have only got passed the bit where you get out of the temple and the guy steals your flask but I had to stop playing as it was giving me a headache.  The game starts with you in a temple where you have to fight a man that looks like he was made out of cardboard by a three year old. The fighting is literally F to block and click the mouse buttons to kill the guy.  However, when you kill him, he disappears somewhere (I would probably find out where if I carried on playing).  The fighting in this game, to say it's a survival game, should be intense and exciting, but turns out to be a big pile of poop, pressing a button every now and then.

Then you are posed with the question of, should I save this woman?  Because in the game, he says that it could kill him if he saves her, but if you do save her, nothing actually happens to you or her... she just sits where she was for the next year or so.

The game tells you what to do but not where to do it, so either tell us what to do, or not at all.  It's really annoying having a survival game that tells you what to do after 2 minutes of exploration.  Then, when something actually happens, for example; you see someone, in a normal survival game, it starts to get really intense and exciting, but in this game, it zooms really weirdly taking all of the intensity out of it.

Then we get onto the buugs... where do I start?

First off, when I went down into the depth of the temple (a couple of feet down under ground), I found a gun and thought that this was a turning point for the game.  Maybe I could now choose whether to fight loud or go in really stealthy, but no, as soon as the next cut-scene comes, the gun was taken out of my inventory never to be seen again.

Secondly, when things start to fall, things hover in the air (again, could be part of the game) but for me, you can't get close to the rocks without there being an invisable wall.  This makes the 'survival' game really restrictive.   When I was trying to do a simple task of walking down the stairs, I couldn't as there was a rock above me.  I tried to crouch, thinking that maybe I needed to, but nope, that didn't work either.

This game is terrible and I wouldn't even wish it onto my worst enemy.

Whatever you do, do not waste £15 on this game.  I wouldn't even spend 50p on it, this game should be free, heck, they should pay us to play it.

How can I get my money back?
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

Trying to exit the game after my 47 minutes of buggy playtime was an experience in itself. My system hung on a black screen for around 10 minutes (couldn't even CTRL+ALT+DEL), and my computer was slow for another 10 or so minutes after that with the harddrive being hammered the whole time. It even managed to crash the audio driver in Ventrillo (which I was logged into in the background). The error message said something about too much data being forced through the sound driver.

Overall, my experiences with Day One were not unique, and I just cannot recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: Holy god. I bought this game for 3$ on steam (had a dollar in my wallet no clue how) and my god let me tell you something about this masterpiece. These guys don't ♥♥♥♥ around with sound or AI - none of that. This is a next level game. The challenge isn't like all of those yesteryear products that force you to deal with the games mechanics or clear cut challenges. Nope. This game, just figuring out what you can do is the challenge. I dont know where they came up with the idea for this iconic title, but let me tell you now, it belongs in the history books!

reviewText:
Before I even get started on my review, I would like to stress one very, Very important thing to you about this game: DO NOT BUY IT! The first time I started up the game, it took several minutes to load up, and when I finally reached the main menu, it was laggy as hell and the music was stuttering. My computer is not the best one on the market, but it can run other new games, like Rust, perfectly and without any issues. And the real kicker was that none of the advanced graphics options were even turned on by default!

Once I fixed the graphics issues, I started the game up. The first thing I noticed was that the character animation is sloppy, and is honestly done half-♥♥♥♥♥. The gameplay feels lazy, like it was something that should have been made for windows 95. Playing the original Unreal is a better experience, and a far more visually enjoyable one as well. I won't even get into all of the terrible things about this game, but don't waste your money on it. Even if it goes free for a weekend, DO NOT BUY IT! It's games like these that are a blemish on the industry, and if this studio goes under, I don't think anyone will be sad about it.

reviewText:
This is actually an achievement. No, really. Seriously. This game is an achievement.

Think about how far we've come as a medium. Think about the unfathomable number of man-hours invested in learning about game design, the massive leaps in technology, the unending array of middleware available for developers of all levels. Think about how much awful shovelware existed for old systems, think about how many games were made by people who had no idea what they were doing, think about how many commecial products came out that simply Did Not Work.

It is an honest-to-god achievement, in this day and age, to release a game that is an honest-to-god contender for Worst Game Ever.

Day One: Garry's Incident, you are gaming history. Congratulations.

reviewText:
Just beat the Story Mode.  Ugh... What a waste.

I mean, REALLY short.
I'm playing, thinking, well this isn't so bad... then boom, game just ends.
So silly.

Only pick this game up if it's a dollar.

Crafting is a joke, since you never really need it.
Traps are buggy.
Enemies aren't even a threat.
Level design was ok I suppose.
Music was annoying.

reviewText: It's actually a very good game. My $7,000,000,000 computer over at NASA can run this game at a smooth 20fps. The combat and stealth systems are completely flawless. I believe that they worked very hard on these stealth and combat controls. The combat is very fast paced and definitaly puts your life on the line. The tactic that always works for me personally, is to crouch as soon as I can low health. This way, the enemies can't hit me. I can then easily run away to the camp. When I do decide to fight, its very difficult and makes my heart race. As long as I keep hitting the enemy, they won't move. At all.\n\nOverall, this is a great game. Just fix the god damn monkeys, holy crap their poop does a lot of damage. 10/10, would buy this game for all of steam.

reviewText:
This game. Oh this game. Is absolutely terrible I mean ok the graphics are mediocre and atleast draws the players attention away from the teleporting panthers, floating dead tribal priestesses and trees which you and NPCs can no-clip through. This game has an awkward combat system and if you have played the MOBA, League of Legends the combat system is very similar to the playstyle of the champion, Tryndamere as it is a simple as spam click your mouse to kill overpowered enemies with one shot capabilities.

The game is extremely close to being unplayable as the bugs and glitches ruin the gameplay as the no-clipping of NPCs and the player breaks the game and is frustrating when you try to hunt a monkey with an unlimited pile of rocks and it just runs through a tree and if you are trying to escape from an enemy you end up getting stuck in an invisible wall. The performance of this game is paralysing as at low or high graphics I always seem to dip below 30fps which is appalling as a fully released game isn't even optimised to perform at or above 60fps without any dips. The storyline can be destroyed as I was testing if the game was buggy (which it is) I accidentally killed the NPC who gave me a quest and this is terrible(I never got my flask back ;_;)

I still think this game has a lot of potential as this concept is amazing! Who wouldn't want a survival game where you can hunt and live in the wild. It also strays away from the zombie environment other survival games feature which is perfect as I would prefer a variation and since it didn't take that path it doesn't fail as hard as other zombie survival games (WarZ).

Final Verdict: This game is extremely unpolished and doesn't live up to the standards we gamers expect but the concept is amazing and I really would like to see and improvment in the near future but for now I don't think it is a great game

2/10

reviewText:
I hate this game.

Graphics: 5/10 the terrain, foliage and grass are decent but character models not so much

Sound and Music: 10/10 can't really screw up sound and music

Combat: 2/10 there is no stealth, enemies randomly aggro when they feel like it no matter if you are crouched or behind them or behind cover or anything, the combat feels bland and dated
the enemy AI is almost non existent. Blood effects terrible.

Features, Plot and Storyline: Depressing, Garry should just put one in his temple and end it all. You have to consume alcohol to ward off the DT's? Nice try at trying to be original, but it is just downright depressing. Crafting is pretty lame.
